Citation: Chen, Z. et al. (2023). The contribution of Neanderthal introgression and natural selection to neurodegenerative diseases. Neurobiology of Disease, 180, 106082
Study_type: GWAS summary statistics analysis; stratified-LDSC heritability partitioning
Populations_studied: European ancestry
Introgression_definition: Posterior probability of Neanderthal admixture (LA metric)
Specific_traits: Alzheimer’s disease; Parkinson’s disease; Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)
Notes: Genome-wide analysis only; no variant-level effects; European ancestry only; negative findings

Citation: Dannemann, M. et al. (2022). Neandertal introgression partitions the genetic landscape of neuropsychiatric disorders and associated behavioral phenotypes. Translational Psychiatry, 12, 433
Study_type: GWAS summary statistics analysis; enrichment comparison of introgressed vs frequency-matched non-archaic variants
Populations_studied: UK Biobank; NESDA; Biobank Japan; Estonian Biobank; FinnGen; deCode
Introgression_definition: Archaic marker SNPs (aSNPs) tagging Neanderthal introgressed haplotypes defined via absence in Africans, presence in Neanderthal genomes, and long haplotypes
Specific_traits: Smoking behaviour; alcohol consumption; chronotype/sleep; pain; mood-related traits
Notes: Focuses on behavioural endophenotypes rather than disease diagnosis; enrichment driven by a subset of strong-effect loci; multi-cohort replication; variant-level results exist but not exhaustive

Citation: Esteller-Cucala, P. et al. (2020). Genomic analysis of the natural history of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder using Neanderthal and ancient Homo sapiens samples. Scientific Reports, 10, 8622
Study_type: GWAS meta-analysis integration; ancient DNA analysis; selection inference (ABC-DL, tSDS); introgression enrichment
Populations_studied: Ancient Homo sapiens (Pre-Neolithic, Near East, Neolithic Europe); modern Europeans; modern Africans; Neanderthal introgressed haplotypes
Introgression_definition: Neanderthal introgressed tag SNPs; comparison of effect sizes of introgressed vs non-introgressed alleles
Specific_traits: Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
Notes: Focuses on evolutionary dynamics rather than direct phenotype association; uses ancient DNA and modelling; ADHD GWAS limited to European ancestry; variant-level results aggregated

Citation: Faux, P. et al. (2023). Neanderthal introgression in SCN9A impacts mechanical pain sensitivity. Communications Biology, 6, 958
Study_type: Population genetics; introgression mapping; experimental pain phenotyping (QST); association analysis
Populations_studied: CANDELA cohort (Latin Americans); QST cohort (Colombians); 1000 Genomes reference populations
Introgression_definition: Neanderthal introgressed haplotypes inferred via admixtureHMM and local ancestry (Vindija Neanderthal reference)
Specific_traits: Mechanical pain sensitivity; pain sensitization after mustard oil (POST_MPT)
Notes: Strong LD between variants limits separation of individual effects; effects specific to mechanical pain modality; admixed Latin American populations enable detection

Citation: Gregory, M.D. et al. (2021). Neanderthal-derived genetic variation in living humans relates to schizophrenia diagnosis, to psychotic symptom severity, and to dopamine synthesis. American Journal of Medical Genetics Part B: Neuropsychiatric Genetics, 186(5), 329–338
Journal: Am J Med Genet B Neuropsychiatr Genet
Study_type: Case-control genetic association; quantitative symptom analysis; PET neuroimaging
Populations_studied: European-ancestry schizophrenia cases and controls (NIMH, GAIN, non-GAIN, Ashkenazi Jewish cohorts); healthy European controls for PET
Introgression_definition: Genome-wide Neanderthal admixture quantified using NeanderScore (enhanced D-statistic)
Specific_traits: Schizophrenia diagnosis; positive psychotic symptoms; dopamine synthesis capacity
Notes: Uses genome-wide admixture score rather than specific loci; modest effect sizes; mechanistic inference via dopamine PET; European ancestry only

Citation: Zeberg, H. et al. (2020). A Neanderthal sodium channel increases pain sensitivity in present-day humans. Current Biology, 30, 3465–3469.e4
Study_type: Functional assay; electrophysiology; population genetics association
Populations_studied: Xenopus oocytes; HEK293T cells; 1000 Genomes populations; UK Biobank (British ancestry)
Introgression_definition: Archaic SNPs and haplotypes defined by absence in Africans, presence in Neanderthal genomes, LD structure, and tract length
Specific_traits: Pain sensitivity; nociception
Notes: Strong functional evidence linking introgressed coding variants to nociceptive physiology; low allele frequency in Europeans; combines wet-lab and population data

Citation: McArthur, E., Rinker, D.C. & Capra, J.A. (2021). Quantifying the contribution of Neanderthal introgression to the heritability of complex traits. Nature Communications, 12, 4481
Study_type: GWAS summary statistics analysis; partitioned heritability (S-LDSC); signed LD profile regression (SLDP)
Populations_studied: European-ancestry GWAS (UK Biobank, FinnGen); 1000 Genomes EUR LD reference; Altai and Vindija Neanderthal genomes
Introgression_definition: Introgressed regions and variants inferred using Sprime and S*; subsets defined by Altai-matching and Vindija-matching Neanderthal alleles
Phenotype_domains: Cognitive; Psychiatric; Circadian; Pain; Immune; Metabolic; Dermatological; Respiratory; Skeletal
Specific_traits: Sunburn; skin & hair traits; autoimmune disease; chronotype; bone density; lung capacity; menopause age; schizophrenia; anorexia
Notes: Genome-wide polygenic analysis; no single causal genes asserted; candidate regions discussed illustratively (e.g. GRB10, BNC2) without mechanistic validation; European-focused

Citation: Reilly, P.F. et al. (2022). The contribution of Neanderthal introgression to modern human traits. Current Biology, 32, R970–R983
Study_type: Narrative review; synthesis of population genetics, GWAS/PheWAS, eQTL and functional studies
Populations_studied: Global modern human populations; ancient hominin genomes (reviewed literature)
Introgression_definition: Review of published introgression maps, haplotypes, and archaic ancestry inference methods
Phenotype_domains: Cognitive; Psychiatric; Circadian; Addiction; Pain; Immune; Metabolic; Pigmentation
Specific_traits: Mood disorders; smoking; chronotype; pain sensitivity; immune response; metabolic traits; brain morphology (globularity)
Loci_level: Region; haplotype; SNP (reported from cited studies)
Notes: Review article; no new data; integrates multiple primary studies across phenotypes and methods

Citation: Gunz, P. et al. (2019). Neandertal introgression sheds light on modern human endocranial globularity. Current Biology, 29, 120–127.e5
Study_type: GWAS; neuroimaging genetics; morphometric analysis
Populations_studied: Modern humans with MRI brain imaging; comparative Neanderthal fossil endocasts
Introgression_definition: Neanderthal introgressed haplotypes identified from published introgression maps and association with modern human genomic variants
Specific_traits: Endocranial globularity; brain shape variation
Notes: Combines fossil morphology with modern neuroimaging; focuses on brain shape rather than clinical phenotype; variant effects inferred via association not functional manipulation

Citation: Pauly, R., Johnson, L., Feltus, F.A. & Casanova, E.L. (2024). Enrichment of a subset of Neanderthal polymorphisms in autistic probands and siblings. Molecular Psychiatry, 29, 3452–3461
Study_type: Case–control enrichment analysis; whole-exome sequencing; SNP frequency and QTL analysis
Populations_studied: SPARK autistic probands and unaffected siblings (US); ethnically matched GTEx and 1000 Genomes controls (black non-Hispanic, white Hispanic, white non-Hispanic)
Introgression_definition: Predefined Neanderthal-derived SNP set (Sankararaman et al.); enrichment of rare (<1%) and common (≥1%) variants relative to matched controls
Specific_traits: Autism spectrum disorder; comorbid intellectual disability; epilepsy; language regression
Notes: Focuses on SNP-level enrichment rather than genome-wide ancestry; WES-based; population-specific results; gene-level discussion is associative, not mechanistic

Citation: Rinker, D.C., Simonti, C.N., McArthur, E., Shaw, D., Hodges, E. & Capra, J.A. (2020). Neanderthal introgression reintroduced functional ancestral alleles lost in Eurasian populations. Nature Ecology & Evolution, 4, 1332–1341
Study_type: Population genetics; evolutionary modelling; eQTL analysis; MPRA; luciferase functional assays
Populations_studied: 1000 Genomes Eurasian populations (EUR, EAS, SAS); sub-Saharan African populations (YRI); GTEx tissues; cell lines (LCLs, K562, HepG2)
Introgression_definition: Distinguishes Neanderthal-derived alleles (NDAs) from reintroduced ancestral alleles (RAs) based on LD with Neanderthal tag SNPs, ancestral state, and African allele presence
Phenotype_domains: Cognitive; Psychiatric; Circadian; Immune; Metabolic; Neurodevelopmental (indirect via regulatory effects)
Specific_traits: Broad trait associations via GWAS Catalog; gene expression regulation (eQTL); no single disorder focus
Notes: Focuses on regulatory and evolutionary mechanisms rather than direct phenotype association; trait links largely indirect via GWAS and eQTL; strong functional validation at exemplar loci (e.g. HDHD5)

Citation: Simonti, C.N. et al. (2016). The phenotypic legacy of admixture between modern humans and Neanderthals. Science, 351(6274), 737–741
Study_type: PheWAS; GWAS-based association; variance partitioning (GCTA)
Populations_studied: European-ancestry adults from the eMERGE Network (USA; ~28,000 individuals)
Introgression_definition: Neanderthal haplotypes inferred via S* and comparison with Altai Neanderthal genome; high-confidence Neanderthal SNP set
Phenotype_domains: Psychiatric; Neurological; Immune; Dermatological; Metabolic; Addiction
Specific_traits: Depression; mood disorders; actinic keratosis; hypercoagulable state; tobacco use disorder; obesity
Notes: Large-scale association study; phenotype inference from EHR data; no causal claims; gene mentions are locus-anchoring not mechanistic

Citation: Skov, L. et al. (2020). The nature of Neanderthal introgression revealed by 27,566 Icelandic genomes. Nature, 582, 78–83
Study_type: Whole-genome sequencing; archaic fragment detection; population genetics; GWAS-style association testing
Populations_studied: Icelandic population (27,566 individuals); African outgroup from 1000 Genomes
Introgression_definition: Archaic fragments inferred using HMM without conditioning on archaic reference genomes; classification via similarity to Altai/Vindija Neanderthal and Denisovan genomes
Specific_traits: Height; blood traits; prostate-specific antigen; haemoglobin measures (limited set)
Notes: Primarily descriptive and evolutionary; phenotype analysis is conservative and largely negative; focuses on fragment discovery and validation rather than trait mechanisms

Citation: Srinivasan, S. et al. (2016). Genetic markers of human evolution are enriched in schizophrenia. Biological Psychiatry, 80(4), 284–292
Study_type: GWAS summary-statistics analysis; polygenic enrichment; conditional FDR; evolutionary annotation analysis
Populations_studied: European-ancestry GWAS cohorts (Psychiatric Genomics Consortium and other large consortia)
Introgression_definition: Neanderthal Selective Sweep (NSS) score used as proxy for divergence between modern humans and Neanderthals; not direct introgressed tracts
Specific_traits: Schizophrenia (primary); height (secondary); BMI and other traits tested
Notes: Does not analyse introgressed haplotypes directly; NSS is an evolutionary proxy, not explicit introgression; gene mentions are candidate and not mechanistic

Citation: Srinivasan, S. et al. (2018). Enrichment of genetic markers of recent human evolution in educational and cognitive traits. Scientific Reports, 8, 12585
Study_type: GWAS summary-statistics analysis; polygenic enrichment; stratified LD-score regression using evolutionary annotations
Populations_studied: Large European-ancestry GWAS cohorts (UK Biobank, SSGAC, CHARGE, GIANT)
Introgression_definition: Post-Neanderthal Selective Sweep (PNSS) regions used as proxy for human-specific positive selection after divergence from Neanderthals
Specific_traits: Educational attainment (years of education); college completion; general cognitive ability (fluid intelligence)
Notes: Uses evolutionary sweep proxies rather than explicit introgressed tracts; no variant- or gene-level causal claims; enrichment is polygenic and indirect

Citation: Kendall, C. et al. (2025). Adaptive introgression in modern human circadian rhythm genes. npj Biological Timing and Sleep, 2, 41
Study_type: Population genomics; introgression mapping (SPrime); selection scans; GWAS overlap; eQTL enrichment
Populations_studied: 76 worldwide non-African populations (HGDP + 1000 Genomes); archaic reference genomes (Altai, Vindija, Chagyrskaya Neanderthals; Denisova)
Introgression_definition: Archaic introgressed segments inferred using SPrime and matched to archaic genomes; adaptive introgression tested via multiple selection statistics
Specific_traits: Chronotype (morningness/eveningness); sleep duration; daytime napping; schizophrenia and bipolar disorder (protective associations); respiratory and inflammatory traits
Notes: Broad multi-population study; strong evidence for adaptive introgression but gene- and variant-level effects largely indirect; extensive pleiotropy; functional validation not performed

Citation: Barker, H.R. et al. (2025). Evolution is in the details: Regulatory differences in modern human and Neanderthal. Computational and Structural Biotechnology Journal, 27, 2298–2312
Study_type: Regulatory comparison; TF binding site prediction; comparative genomics; transcriptomic integration
Populations_studied: Modern human reference genome; Neanderthal genomes (Altai/Vindija lineage via Neanderthal Genome Project SNPs); human brain and immune transcriptomic datasets
Introgression_definition: Modern human vs Neanderthal promoter SNPs affecting transcription-factor binding affinity; regulatory divergence without introgression tract inference
Specific_traits: Autism spectrum disorder; schizophrenia; language/speech-related traits; brain development
Notes: Focuses on regulatory divergence rather than introgressed haplotypes; does not test population-level introgression frequencies; strong mechanistic/regulatory evidence using in-silico TFBS and transcriptomic integration

Citation: Trujillo, C.A. et al. (2021). Reintroduction of the archaic variant of NOVA1 in cortical organoids alters neurodevelopment. Science, 371(6530), eaax2537
Study_type: Functional validation; CRISPR genome editing; cortical organoids; single-cell RNA-seq; electrophysiology (MEA)
Populations_studied: Human iPSC-derived cortical organoids; modern human genetic background; comparative archaic genomes (Altai, Vindija Neanderthals; Denisovan)
Introgression_definition: Human-specific fixed derived coding variant identified by absence in archaic genomes; archaic allele reintroduced experimentally (not population-level introgression)
Specific_traits: Neurodevelopment; synaptic connectivity; neuronal network activity; autism- and schizophrenia-related pathways
Notes: Experimental organoid model; focuses on a single gene and coding change; not a population introgression study; strong mechanistic evidence but limited evolutionary scope

Citation: Caporale, A.L. et al. (2024). The Human Accelerated Region HAR202 controls NPAS3 expression in the developing forebrain displaying differential enhancer activity between modern and archaic human sequences. Molecular Biology and Evolution, 41(10), msae186
Study_type: Regulatory enhancer assays; comparative genomics; transgenic zebrafish and mouse reporter assays; CRISPR/Cas9 knockout
Populations_studied: Transgenic zebrafish; transgenic mice; mouse embryos; human population datasets; archaic genomes
Introgression_definition: Human accelerated region (HAR202) regulatory divergence; introgression inferred via Sprime
Specific_traits: Forebrain development; NPAS3 expression
Notes: Strong regulatory and functional evidence; enhancer activity tested in vivo; focuses on regulatory divergence; introgression inferred for East Asian groups

Citation: Fajardo, S., Kozowyk, P.R.B. & Langejans, G.H.J. (2023). Measuring ancient technological complexity and its cognitive implications using Petri nets. Scientific Reports, 13, 14961
Study_type: Archaeological modelling; computational process modelling (Petri nets); experimental archaeology synthesis
Populations_studied: Experimental reconstructions of Neanderthal birch tar production methods; no genetic samples
Introgression_definition: Not applicable (no genetics; technology–cognition inference only)
Specific_traits: Planning; working memory; inhibitory control; learning; technological complexity
Notes: Archaeological/computational study only; no genetic, introgression, or variant-level data; cognition inferred from technology structure rather than biology

Citation: Gittelman, R.M. et al. (2016). Archaic hominin admixture facilitated adaptation to out-of-Africa environments. Current Biology, 26, 3375–3382
Study_type: Population genomics; introgression mapping; coalescent simulations; eQTL integration; GWAS overlap
Populations_studied: 1,523 non-African individuals: East Asian, European, South Asian, Melanesian (1000 Genomes + Melanesia cohorts)
Introgression_definition: High-frequency archaic haplotypes identified via LD-clustered archaic tag SNPs; adaptive introgression inferred using frequency outliers and simulations
Specific_traits: Immune response (TLR1/6/10, OAS1/2/3); skin and eye pigmentation (OCA2); inflammatory and autoimmune traits
Notes: Genome-wide adaptive introgression study; phenotype links largely indirect via GWAS/eQTL; limited brain-specific focus; strong population-genetic evidence

Citation: Kaczanowska, J. et al. (2022). Molecular archaeology of human cognitive traits. Cell Reports, 40, 111287
Study_type: Comparative evolutionary genomics; dN/dS (ω) phylogenetic analysis; computational neuroanatomy; brain network mapping
Populations_studied: Mammalian species set including mouse, primates, Denisovan, Neanderthal, and anatomically modern humans; Allen Human Brain Atlas (expression)
Introgression_definition: Regulatory and coding sequence divergence inferred via branch-specific dN/dS; no introgressed tracts analysed
Specific_traits: Language; working memory; strategic thinking; attention; motor control; social cognition
Loci_level: Gene sets; evolutionary branches (no discrete loci)
Notes: No population-level introgression analysis; no trait associations tested in modern cohorts; genes discussed as multigenic clusters rather than causal loci

Citation: Kang, J. et al. (2023). Functional archaic DNA regulates molecular variation and is associated with disease risk across global populations. bioRxiv, doi:10.1101/2023.04.26.538367
Study_type: Population genomics; eQTL enrichment analysis; regulatory genomics; phenotype enrichment analysis
Populations_studied: 1000 Genomes Europeans and East Asians; GTEx European tissues; Japanese immune-cell eQTL dataset
Introgression_definition: Archaic SNPs defined by overlap with Neanderthal or Denisovan genomes, absence in African populations, and segregation in EUR/EAS; functional impact assessed via overlap with eQTLs
Specific_traits: Gene expression regulation; disease-associated CNVs; developmental delay (shared enrichment)
Notes: Preprint (not peer-reviewed); focuses on regulatory and disease-risk enrichment rather than specific traits; gene-level effects are aggregate and non-causal

Citation: Alagöz, G. et al. (2022). Using neuroimaging genomics to investigate the evolution of human brain structure. PNAS, 119(40), e2200638119
Journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Study_type: GWAS of neuroimaging traits; partitioned heritability (LDSC); evolutionary annotation analysis; neuroimaging genomics
Populations_studied: UK Biobank participants of European ancestry (∼30,000); ancient Neanderthal genomes for annotations
Introgression_definition: Neanderthal introgressed SNPs and SNPs in perfect LD; archaic deserts; human-gained enhancers defined from comparative epigenomics
Specific_traits: Cortical surface area (hemispheric, regional); white-matter connectivity (uncinate fasciculus); speech-related regions
Notes: Polygenic and heritability-based; no direct trait-association testing with introgressed variants; gene-level example (ZIC4) used illustratively rather than as causal introgression evidence

Citation: Kozowyk, P.R.B. et al. (2023). Scaling Palaeolithic tar production processes exponentially increases behavioural complexity. Scientific Reports, 13, 14709
Study_type: Archaeological modelling; Petri net analysis; experimental archaeology
Populations_studied: Experimental reconstructions of Neanderthal birch-tar production; no genetic samples
Introgression_definition: Not applicable (no genetics; behavioural modelling only)
Specific_traits: Technological complexity; inhibitory control; attention; cooperation
Notes: Purely archaeological/behavioural modelling; no genetic or introgression data; cognition inferred from process complexity rather than biology

Citation: Kun, E., Sohail, M. & Narasimhan, V.M. (2025). The trait-specific timing of accelerated genomic change in the human lineage. Cell Genomics, 5, 100740
Study_type: GWAS enrichment analysis; stratified LD score regression (S-LDSC); gene-overlap enrichment (HARE); comparative evolutionary genomics
Populations_studied: Large European-ancestry GWAS and UK Biobank imaging cohorts; multiple published GWAS datasets (≈70 traits)
Introgression_definition: Uses predefined evolutionary genomic annotations (human-gained enhancers/promoters, HARs, ancient selective sweeps, Neanderthal-introgressed alleles); no de novo introgression inference
Phenotype_domains: Cognitive; Neurodevelopmental; Psychiatric; Skeletal; Respiratory; Dermatological; Reproductive
Specific_traits: Brain MRI traits (visual cortex, thalamus, white-matter tracts); autism; neuroticism; skeletal proportions; lung function; reproductive timing
Notes: Broad integrative framework; polygenic and annotation-based; no single causal loci asserted; gene mentions are aggregate and illustrative

Citation: Levi, G. et al. (2021). DLX5/6 GABAergic expression affects social vocalization: implications for human evolution. Molecular Biology and Evolution, 38(11), 4748–4764
Study_type: Functional mouse genetics; behavioural phenotyping; population genetics; haplotype introgression analysis
Populations_studied: Mouse models (Dlx5/6VgatCre); modern human populations (1000 Genomes); European semi-supercentenarians; archaic genomes (Altai, Vindija Neanderthals; Denisovan)
Introgression_definition: Introgressed Neanderthal haplotype inferred via LD structure, haplotype length, absence in Africans, similarity to Vindija Neanderthal genome
Specific_traits: Social vocalization; sociability; speech-related traits; aging/longevity (secondary)
Notes: Strong functional animal evidence combined with population-genetic introgression analysis; human phenotype associations largely indirect; pleiotropic locus affecting brain, craniofacial and social traits

Citation: Mangan, R.J. et al. (2022). Adaptive sequence divergence forged new neurodevelopmental enhancers in humans. Cell, 185, 4587–4603
Study_type: Comparative genomics; evolutionary selection analysis; regulatory genomics; in vivo single-cell STARR-seq; enhancer reporter assays
Populations_studied: Modern human populations (1000 Genomes Africans & non-Africans); Neanderthal and Denisovan genomes; developing mouse brain (functional assays)
Introgression_definition: Human Ancestor Quickly Evolved Regions (HAQERs) defined by rapid sequence divergence from the human–chimpanzee ancestor; not introgressed tracts but shared hominin regulatory sequence
Specific_traits: Neurodevelopmental enhancers; cortical development; schizophrenia; bipolar disorder; autism-related loci (enrichment)
Notes: Focuses on regulatory divergence rather than introgression; functional validation in mouse cortex; disease links are enrichment-based, not causal; not a population introgression study

Citation: Moriano, J. & Boeckx, C. (2020). Modern human changes in regulatory regions implicated in cortical development. BMC Genomics, 21, 304
Study_type: Integrative regulatory genomics; paleogenomics; chromatin state and Hi-C integration; single-cell RNA-seq network analysis
Populations_studied: Developing human cortex (5–20 post-conception weeks); single-cell progenitors; Neanderthal and Denisovan genomes (comparative)
Introgression_definition: Modern human single-nucleotide changes in enhancers/promoters where Neanderthal/Denisovan carry the ancestral allele (no introgressed tracts analysed)
Specific_traits: Cortical development; neurogenesis; schizophrenia-linked loci; language-related regulation
Notes: Focuses on modern-human derived regulatory changes rather than introgression; disease links are enrichment-based; mechanistic inference via regulatory and network context, not direct functional perturbation

Citation: Hsieh, P.H. et al. (2019). Adaptive archaic introgression of copy number variants and the discovery of previously unknown human genes. Science, 366(6463), eaax2083
Study_type: Population genomics; CNV discovery; selection scans (PBS, Tajima’s D); introgression tests (fD, S*); long-read assembly; FISH; Iso-Seq
Populations_studied: Melanesians (SGDP, HGDP; blood-derived samples); global comparison populations; archaic genomes (Altai Neanderthal, Vindija Neanderthal, Denisovan)
Introgression_definition: Archaic introgressed copy-number variants inferred via CNV stratification plus introgression statistics on flanking SNVs, haplotype age, and absence in Africans
Phenotype_domains: None specific (functional inference); Immune; Metabolic; Developmental (indirect)
Specific_traits: Local adaptation; metabolism; immune response; developmental risk loci (e.g. 16p11.2, 8p21.3)
Loci_level: CNV; duplication; deletion; multi-allelic CNV; gene
Notes: Focus on structural variation rather than SNPs; phenotypic effects inferred indirectly; strong evolutionary and population-genetic evidence; limited direct trait association; highlights CNVs as under-studied adaptive substrate

Citation: Rong, S. et al. (2023). Large-scale functional screen identifies genetic variants with splicing effects in modern and archaic humans. PNAS, 120(21), e2218308120
Journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
Study_type: Massively parallel splicing reporter assay (MaPSy); comparative genomics; enrichment analysis (SpliceAI, GTEx sQTL/eQTL); evolutionary inference
Populations_studied: Modern humans (1KGP, gnomAD, GTEx); high-coverage archaic genomes (Altai, Vindija, Chagyrskaya Neanderthals; Denisovan)
Introgression_definition: Lineage-specific and introgressed SNVs defined via allele frequency contrasts between modern and archaic genomes; introgressed and adaptively introgressed sets from published maps (Vernot; Browning; Gittelman; Racimo)
Phenotype_domains: Cognitive; Psychiatric; Immune; Metabolic; Respiratory (trait links indirect)
Specific_traits: Innate immunity (TLR1); extracellular matrix (HSPG2); pain-related pathways (FAAH); hematological and pulmonary traits (fine-mapping overlaps)
Notes: Functional assay in HEK293T cells only; splicing effects may be tissue-specific (brain not directly assayed); focuses on splicing regulation rather than direct phenotype association; strong causal resolution at variant level

Citation: Viscardi, L.H. et al. (2018). Searching for ancient balanced polymorphisms shared between Neanderthals and Modern Humans. Genetics and Molecular Biology, 41(1), 67–81
Study_type: Exome-wide comparative genomics; trans-species SNP analysis; permutation testing; population-genetic statistics (Tajima’s D, Fst)
Populations_studied: Neanderthals (3 high-quality exomes); modern humans (Yoruba, 1000 Genomes)
Introgression_definition: Shared heterozygous exonic SNPs (trans-SNPs) between Neanderthals and Yoruba interpreted as candidates of long-term balancing selection; introgression explicitly controlled for by using African samples
Specific_traits: Schizophrenia-associated loci (immune genes); selected behavioural/neurodevelopmental genes (no global enrichment)
Notes: No phenotype association testing; balancing selection inferred statistically; behavioural relevance largely indirect and speculative; relies on exome data and African reference to avoid introgression effects

Citation: Yermakovich, D. et al. (2023). Long-range regulatory effects of Neandertal DNA in modern humans. Genetics, 223(3), iyac188
Study_type: eQTL integration (GTEx + eQTLGen); transcription-factor network analysis; introgression annotation; selection inference
Populations_studied: Modern non-African humans (GTEx; eQTLGen; Estonian Biobank; 1000 Genomes; SGDP Papuans); archaic reference genomes
Introgression_definition: Neanderthal aSNPs defined by absence in Africans, presence in archaic genomes, LD-supported introgressed haplotypes
Specific_traits: Gene-expression regulation; schizophrenia; immune traits; height and body measures; brain connectivity (indirect)
Notes: Regulatory and network-level inference; trans-effects largely predicted rather than experimentally validated; phenotype links are enrichment-based; strong reliance on expression datasets
